sub_topic: Calculation of standard enthalpy change for a reaction involving solids
message_1:
Calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction between calcium oxide (CaO) and water (H2O) to form calcium hydroxide (Ca(OH)2), given that all species are in their standard state and that the balanced chemical equation is:

CaO(s) + H2O(l) → Ca(OH)2(s)

The standard enthalpies of formation of CaO(s), H2O(l) and Ca(OH)2(s) are -635.1 kJ/mol, -285.8 kJ/mol, and -986.2 kJ/mol respectively.
message_2:
To calculate the standard enthalpy change for the reaction, we can use the following formula:

ΔH_reaction = Σ ΔH_f(products) - Σ ΔH_f(reactants)

where ΔH_reaction is the standard enthalpy change for the reaction, ΔH_f(products) is the sum of the standard enthalpies of formation of the products, and ΔH_f(reactants) is the sum of the standard enthalpies of formation of the reactants.

For this reaction, we have:

ΔH_f(CaO) = -635.1 kJ/mol
ΔH_f(H2O) = -285.8 kJ/mol
ΔH_f(Ca(OH)2) = -986.2 kJ/mol

Now, we can plug these values into the formula:

ΔH_reaction = [ΔH_f(Ca(OH)2)] - [ΔH_f(CaO) + ΔH_f(H2O)]

ΔH_reaction = (-986.2 kJ/mol) - (-635.1 kJ/mol + -285.8 kJ/mol)

ΔH_reaction = (-986.2 kJ/mol) - (-920.9 kJ/mol)

ΔH_reaction = -65.3 kJ/mol

So, the standard enthalpy change for the reaction between calcium oxide and water to form calcium hydroxide is -65.3 kJ/mol.
